moves.1. g4 d5 2. Bg2 Bxg4 3. c4 c6 4. cxd5 cx: The starting position for all the games.
moves.9. d4: White elects not to snap up the loose pawn on his QR7.
moves.12. Nd6 Bxd6: If White wants to swap minor pieces, I'm agreeable.
moves.13. Qxd6 Nb6: I offer to exchange Queens as well.
moves.14. Qg3 Bg6: Shielding the White Queen's attacking line.
moves.15. f4 h6: Creating a retreat, if it proves needed.
moves.16. Nh3 Ne4: Placing my Knight on a strong outpost.
moves.18. Rg1: A useless move. 18 O-O or 18 B-K3 enabling 19 O-O-O were far better options. White has played well up to this point but now is the time to get the King out of the center.
moves.18... Nc4: Placing my other Knight on a strong central outpost as well.
moves.19. Qb3 Qh4+: I exploit the fact that White failed to secure his King's safety by castling earlier.
moves.20. Kd1 Nf2+: Now I force the win of a oiece.
moves.21. Nxf2 Qxf2: Either the Rook or Bishop must fall. 22 B-Q3 fails against ... NxB.
moves.22. Re1 Qxg2: I now have a technically easy win.
moves.23. e4: This blunder enables me to force mate.
